metadata.document_name: 29. Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks
metadata.source_pdf: 29. Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf
judges: C. HARI SHANKAR J U D G M E N T (ORAL) % 22.02.2023 1.
metadata.court_name: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
key_issues: The appellant's trade mark application was rejected due to similarity with an earlier mark, raising issues of likelihood of confusion among consumers.
The Trade Marks Act 1999, Section 11(1) was cited as the basis for rejecting the application, which relates to identical or similar marks and goods/services.
The appellant claimed prior use of the mark since 2014, while the earlier mark had a user claim of 2005, potentially impacting the decision.
The Registrar's First Examination Report objected to the registration, citing an earlier mark "M/s JAINSONS LITES" with a similar description of goods.
The appellant argued that their mark was a highly stylised representation of their trade name and included the year of adoption, distinguishing it from the earlier mark.
The appellant also emphasized their goodwill and reputation since 1978, which may be relevant to the assessment of likelihood of confusion.
The respondent's mark "M/s JAINSONS LITES" was filed by Mr. Rakesh Jain, potentially raising issues of ownership and priority.
The appellant's response to the FER was deemed unsatisfactory, leading to the rejection of their application.
The unique colour combination of the appellant's mark, specifically claimed during the application process, may be a relevant factor in assessing distinctiveness.
The impugned order highlighted the similarity of goods and services between the two marks, which contributed to the likelihood of confusion.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary: JAINSONS LIGHTS PRIVATE LIMITED vs. THE REGISTRAR OF TRADE MARKS**

**Background:**
The appellant, JAINSONS LIGHTS PRIVATE LIMITED, filed an application for registration of the trade mark "JAINSONS LIGHTS" (the subject mark) in Class 11 for various lighting goods and installations. The application claimed user of the mark since 2014. The Registrar of Trade Marks, however, objected to the registration of the subject mark due to its deceptive similarity to an earlier mark "M/s JAINSONS LITES" (Mark No. 2242763), which had a user claim of 2005.

**Legal Issues:**
The main issue in this case was whether the subject mark was deceptively similar to the earlier mark "M/s JAINSONS LITES", and whether the registration of the subject mark would cause confusion among the public.

**Arguments:**
The appellant argued that the subject mark was a highly stylized representation of the predominant feature of the trade name of the appellant, which was Jainsons Lights Pvt. Ltd., and included the year 1978, representing the year of adoption of the mark "JAINSONS". The appellant also claimed that the subject mark had a unique color combination of teal and black, which was specifically claimed while applying for registration. Furthermore, the appellant emphasized the goodwill and reputation it had gained since 1978.

**Court Findings:**
The Senior Examiner rejected the appellant's application, citing the following grounds:

1. Phonetic similarity between the subject mark and Mark No. 2242763.
2. Conceptual similarity between the two marks.
3. The appellant failed to establish the significance and uniqueness in the adoption of the trade mark, as the prefix "JAINSONS" was a common English term.
4. The user claim of the appellant was subsequent to the user of the cited mark.

**Decision:**
The High Court of Delhi at New Delhi upheld the decision of the Registrar of Trade Marks, rejecting the appellant's application for registration of the subject mark. The court found that the subject mark was deceptively similar to the earlier mark "M/s JAINSONS LITES", and that the registration of the subject mark would cause confusion among the public.

**Rationale:**
The court's decision was based on the principles of trademark law, which aim to prevent confusion among consumers. The court held that the phonetic and conceptual similarities between the two marks, combined with the similar goods and services covered by the marks, would likely cause confusion among the public. The court also took into account the appellant's failure to establish the significance and uniqueness of the trade mark, as well as the subsequent user claim.

**Conclusion:**
In conclusion, the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi rejected the appellant's application for registration of the subject mark due to its deceptive similarity to the earlier mark "M/s JAINSONS LITES". The court's decision highlights the importance of ensuring that trade marks are distinctive and do not cause confusion among consumers. The appellant's failure to establish the significance and uniqueness of the trade mark, combined with the phonetic and conceptual similarities between the two marks, led to the rejection of the application.

--- PAGE 1 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001284 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021  
Page 1 of 8    
 
$~3(Original) 
* 
IN  THE  HIGH  COURT  OF  DELHI  AT  NEW  DELHI 
+  
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021 
 
JAINSONS LIGHTS PRIVATE LIMITED          ..... Appellant 
Through: 
Mr. Vikram Grover and Mr. 
Harish K. Chauhan, Advs. 
 
 
 
 
 
versus 
 
 
THE REGISTRAR OF TRADE MARKS 
      ..... Respondent 
Through: 
Mr. 
Harish 
Vaidyanathan 
Shankar, CGSC 
 
 
CORAM: 
 
HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE C. HARI SHANKAR 
 
 
 
     J U D G M E N T (ORAL) 
% 
 
 
 
     22.02.2023 
 
1. 
Application no. 3487036  was filed by the appellant before the 
Trade 
Marks 
Registry 
for 
registration 
of 
the 
Mark 
 (hereinafter referred to as “the subject mark”) 
in Class 11, for electric lamps, lighting apparatus and installations, 
luminaries chandeliers, lamp shades, lamps, led and fluorescent lights, 
flash lights, lanterns for lighting, lighting fittings and fixtures, 
decorative lighting, light diffusers, ceiling light, wall lights, outdoor 
lights, water proof lights, desk lamps, floor lamps, hanging lamps, 
lighting tubes, light bulbs, security lights, garden lights, mood 
lighting, display lighting etc.  The appellant claimed user of the 
subject mark since 2014.  
 
2. 
The Registrar, vide First Examination Report (FER) dated 7th 
March 2017, objected to the registration of the subject mark.  In the 
FER, “M/s JAINSONS LITES” was cited as an earlier trade mark, for 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.02.2023
15:30:55
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 2 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001284 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021  
Page 2 of 8    
 
which Application No. 2242763, submitted by Mr. Rakesh Jain, 
seeking registration of the mark in Class 11 in respect of “electrical 
fancy lights, electrical goods, items and instruments”, was already in 
existence with user claim of 2005.  The FER objected to the 
registration of the subject mark on the ground that it was deceptively 
similar to the earlier mark “M/s JAINSONS LITES”.  
 
3. 
The appellant submitted his response to the FER on 1st May 
2017. It was sought to be contended, in the response, that the trade 
mark “JAINSONS” had been adopted by the predecessor of the 
appellant in 1978 primarily in respect of lighting goods and was in use 
since then.   The subject mark, it was submitted, was a highly stylised 
representation of the predominant feature of the trade name of the 
appellant, which was Jainsons Lights Pvt. Ltd., and also included 1978 
as representing the year of adoption of the mark “JAINSONS”. 
Moreover, it was submitted that the subject mark was in a unique 
colour combination of teal and black, which was specifically claimed 
while applying for registration of the subject mark.  The reply also 
emphasised the goodwill and reputation that the appellant had gained 
since 1978. 
 
4. 
The impugned order dated 27th April 2020 rejected Application 
No. 3487036 in the following terms: 
“The mark applied for registration is objectionable under following 
provision of the Trade Marks Act, 1999-  
 
The mark applied for registration is identical with /similar to earlier  
trademarks on record, as mentioned in the Examination report and 
by similarity of marks as well as similarity of goods and services 
covered under such marks, there exists a likelihood of confusion in 
the mind of public. As such the registration of the mark is 
objectionable under Section 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act 1999  
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.02.2023
15:30:55
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 3 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001284 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021  
Page 3 of 8    
 
ADV. HARISH appeared and argued and submitted that, the cited 
mark is different, heard, and checked the details of application, it 
appeared that. Reply perused not satisfactory, Deceptively and 
phonetically and conceptually similar registered mark no. 
12242763 with the identical goods are on record, so it will cause 
the confusion to the public and in the market, moreover user claim 
since 2014, and user affidavit submitted along with the evidence in 
support has proved the user since 2014 which is subsequent to the 
user of the cited mark, and adv. also fails to establish the 
significance and uniqueness in the adoption of the trade mark, 
since the prefix is a common English term, as there is phonetically 
similarity with the cited mark, hence no difference between cited 
mark and the applicant mark, so; upon considering the material on 
record and submissions made by the adv. And applicant is fail to 
prove the justification for waving off obj. raised under sec. 11 trade 
Mark Act 1999.” 
 
5. 
With some effort, the court has been able to glean, from the 
impugned order, the grounds on which the Senior Examiner has 
rejected the appellant’s application as 
(i) 
phonetic similarity between the subject mark and Mark 
No. 2242763, 
(ii) 
conceptual similarity between the subject mark and Mark 
No. 2242763, 
(iii) 
the fact that both marks were claimed in respect of 
identical goods/services.  
(iv) 
the possibility, therefore, of confusion to the public were 
both marks to be registered, 
(v) 
the user claim of the appellant, of 2014, being subsequent 
to user claim of Mr. Rakesh Jain in respect of Mark No. 
2242763, which was 2005, and 
(vi) 
lack of significance and uniqueness in the subject mark, 
as “lights” was a common English term. 
 
6. 
Of these findings, no cavil, in the opinion of the court, can be 
taken with the findings no. (i), (iii), (iv) and (v). 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.02.2023
15:30:55
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001284 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021  
Page 4 of 8    
 
 
7. 
The court is in agreement with the Senior Examiner in her 
observation that  
(i)  
the subject mark was phonetically identical to Mark No. 
2242763 as the subject mark was “Jainsons Lights” and Mark 
No. 2242763 was “M/s Jainsons Lites”,  
(ii)  
the registration of the marks were sought in respect of 
identical goods, i.e. electrical lamps, lights, electrical goods and 
fittings etc. and   
(iii)  the claim of user, by the appellant, was subsequent to the 
claim of user of Rakesh Jain in respect of Mark no. 2242763. 
 
8. 
The court is also in agreement with the finding of the Senior 
Examiner that permitting registration of both the marks is likely to 
result in confusion. Section 11(1)(b)1 of the Trade Marks Act 
proscribes registration of a trade mark if, owing to its similarity to an 
earlier trade mark, and the identity of similarity of the goods or 
services covered by the two marks, a likelihood of confusion on the 
part of the public can be said to exist.   
 
9. 
There can be no gainsaying the fact that the mark “Jainsons 
Lights” is similar to the mark “Jainsons Lites”. Both marks were used 
in respect of similar goods and services.  
 
                                          
1 11.  
Relative grounds for refusal of registration. –  
(1)  
Save as provided in Section 12, a trade mark shall not be registered if, because of –  
(a)  
its identity with an earlier trade mark and similarity of goods or services 
covered by the trade mark; or 
(b)  
its similarity to an earlier trade mark and the identity or similarity of the goods 
or services covered by the trade mark, 
there exists a likelihood of confusion on the part of the public, which includes the likelihood of association 
with the earlier trade mark. 
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.02.2023
15:30:55
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001284 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021  
Page 5 of 8    
 
10. 
Mr. Grover has sought to contend that the Senior Examiner as 
erred to note (i) the unique stylised nature of the subject mark, which 
distinguished it from the “Jainsons Lites” mark of Rakesh Jain and (ii) 
the inclusion, in the subject mark, of the phrase “since 1978” which 
was essentially intended to indicate tht the mark “Jainsons”, which 
was the prominent part of the subject mark, had been in use since 
1978. 
 
11. 
As already noted, the aspect of likelihood of confusion, for the 
purposes of Section 11(1)(b) has to be examined from the point of 
view of “the public”, as the clause refers to “likelihood of  confusion 
on the part of the public”.  Insofar as the aspect of confusion, in the 
matter of trade marks is concerned, it is settled that the test has to 
apply from the point of view of a customer of average intelligence and 
imperfect recollection. Viewed from the perspective of such a 
customer, the court cannot characterise the finding, of the Senior 
Examiner, that there is a likelihood of confusion between the subject 
mark “Jainsons Lights” and the earlier mark “Jainsons Lites” as 
arbitrary, or otherwise deserving of interference in appeal, especially 
as both the marks were being used in respect of identical goods. The 
unwary customer of average intelligence and imperfect recollection 
cannot be attributed the perspicacity to be able to recollect that, in one 
case, “lights” was spelt “Lites” and, in the other, “Lights”.  Nor can 
the mere inclusion, in the subject mark, of the words “since 1978”, or 
of the word “M/s” in Mark No. 2242763, be regarded as factors which 
would mitigate the possibility of such confusion arising in the minds 
of the customer of average intelligence and imperfect recollection as 
these are elements of a mark which may change from time to time.   
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.02.2023
15:30:55
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001284 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021  
Page 6 of 8    
 
12. 
Besides, in the 
, the dominant impression 
that the average customer, who views the mark without prior 
familiarity with it, would carry with him, is of “JAINSONS 
LIGHTS”, rather than of “since 1978”.  An average consumer, 
realistically speaking, would identify the appellant from its name 
“JAINSONS LIGHTS”, rather than from the year from which it had 
started using the mark “JAINSONS”.  This reality is apparent from the 
mark itself, in which the “since 1978” slogan is in disproportionately 
small letters, as compared to “JAINSONS LIGHTS”.  If the mythical 
customer of imperfect recollection were to to be asked to recollect the 
mark, he would recollect it as “JAINSONS LIGHTS”, not as 
“JAINSONS LIGHTS SINCE 1978”.  Equally, he would recollect 
Mark No. 2242763 as “JAINSONS LITES”, not as “M/s JAINSONS 
LITES”.   
 
13. 
The Senior Examiner is also correct in her observation that 
“lights” – whether spelt “lights” or “lites” – is an ordinary English 
word.  Perhaps it would be more appropriate to hold that the dominant 
part, whether of “JAINSONS LIGHTS” or “JAINSONS LITES”, is 
“JAINSONS”.  That dominant part, in the two marks, is identical, 
thereby exacerbating the chance of confusion.  
 
14. 
 Mr. Grover has also sought to press into service Sections 122 
and 343 of the Trade Marks Act.  
                                          
2 12.  
Registration in the case of honest concurrent use, etc. – In the case of honest concurrent use or 
of other special circumstances which in the opinion of the Registrar, make it proper so to do, he may permit 
the registration by more than one proprietor of the trade marks which are identical or similar (whether any 
such trade mark is already registered or not) in respect of the same or similar goods or services, subject to 
such conditions and limitations, if any, as the Registrar may think fit to impose. 
3 34.  
Saving for vested rights. – Nothing in this Act shall entitle the proprietor or a registered user of 
registered trade mark to interfere with or restrain the use by any person of a trade mark identical with or 
nearly resembling it in relation to goods or services in relation to which that person or a predecessor in title of 
his has continuously used that trade mark from a date prior –  
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.02.2023
15:30:55
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001284 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021  
Page 7 of 8    
 
15. 
I am, unfortunately, unable to accept his submission that either 
of these provisions would serve to vitiate the impugned order.  Section 
12 permits the Registrar, in an appropriate case, to allow registration 
of a mark which is identical, or similar to an earlier trade mark, where 
the case is one of “honest concurrent use”, or where there are “other 
special circumstances”.  
 
16. 
Mr. Grover seeks to submit that the present case has to be 
regarded as one involving “other special circumstances”, the “special 
circumstance” being that the “Jainsons” mark had been in use by his 
client since 1978.  For this purpose, Mr. Grover seeks to submit that 
Section 12 may be read in conjunction with Section 34 of the Trade 
Marks Act.    
 
17. 
Section 34 of the Trade Marks Act allows the Registrar to 
register a trade mark which is identical with or nearly resembling an 
earlier trade mark, in respect of identical goods or services, provided 
the user of the former is prior in point of time both to registration and 
user of the latter.  
 
18. 
This defence obviously, cannot come to the aid of the appellant, 
as the claim of user of the appellant, in respect of the subject trade 
mark, is of 2014, whereas the user claim of Rakesh Jain in respect of 
Mark No. 2242763 is of 2005.  Though Mr Grover emphasizes that 
the mark “JAINSONS” was being used since 1978, that is irrelevant.  
The court, while applying Section 34, has to take into account the 
                                                                                                                   
(a)  
to the use of the first-mentioned trade mark in relation to those goods or services be the 
proprietor or a predecessor in title of his; or 
(b)  
to the date of registration of the first-mentioned trade mark in respect of those goods or 
services in the name of the proprietor of a predecessor in title of his; 
whichever is the earlier, and the Registrar shall not refuse (on such use being proved) to register the second 
mentioned trade mark by reason only of the registration of the first-mentioned trade mark. 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.02.2023
15:30:55
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 8 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001284 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021  
Page 8 of 8    
 
claim of user in respect of the subject mark which, in the present case, 
is “
”.  “Since 1978” is only a part of the 
complete 
 mark, and user, in respect of the 
complete mark, is claimed, by the appellant itself, since 2014. 
 
19. 
Inasmuch as the appellant itself has claimed user, while 
applying for subject mark, of 2014, it cannot claim prior user over 
Rakesh Jain, so as to entitle it to the benefit of Section 34 of the Trade 
Marks Act.  
 
20. 
For the aforesaid reasons, I do not find that a case for 
interference with impugned order dated 27th April 2020 can be said to 
exist.  
 
21. 
The appeal is accordingly dismissed.  
 
 
 
C. HARI SHANKAR, J. 
 
FEBRUARY 22, 2023 
 
dsn 
 
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.02.2023
15:30:55
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Case Header and Parties
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", a legal proceeding took place in the High Court of Delhi. The case, C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021, involved Jainsons Lights Private Limited (Appellant) and the Registrar of Trade Marks (Respondent). The Appellant was represented by Mr. Vikram Grover and Mr. Harish K. Chauhan, while the Respondent was represented by Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar.

The Appellant had filed an application (No. 3487036) for registration of their trade mark in Class 11, which included electric lamps, lighting apparatus, and installations, among others. The application claimed user of the mark since 2014. However, the Registrar objected to the registration, citing an earlier trade mark "M/s JAINSONS LITES" (Application No. 2242763) with a user claim of 2005.

The Appellant responded to the objection, stating that their mark was a highly stylized representation of their trade name and included the year of adoption (1978). They also emphasized their goodwill and reputation since 1978. Despite this, the impugned order dated April 27, 2020, rejected the application, citing likelihood of confusion with the earlier trade mark under Section 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.

The High Court of Delhi, with Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. Hari Shankar presiding, heard the case and delivered a judgment on February 22, 2023. The details of the judgment are not provided in the given section of the PDF document. (Source: Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf)

The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", a case was filed by Jainsons Lights Private Limited (Appellant) against The Registrar of Trade Marks (Respondent) in the High Court of Delhi. The appellant applied for registration of their mark in Class 11 for various lighting products, claiming usage since 2014. The Registrar objected to the registration, citing an earlier trademark "M/s JAINSONS LITES" in the First Examination Report dated March 7, 2017. The case, C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021, was heard by Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. Hari Shankar, with the appellant represented by Mr. Vikram Grover and Mr. Harish K. Chauhan, and the respondent represented by Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar, CGSC. The judgment was delivered on February 22, 2023. (Source: PDF page 1)

The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the appellant, Jainsons Lights Private Limited, applied for trademark registration (Application No. 3487036) in Class 11 for "electrical fancy lights, electrical goods, items and instruments". The application was objected to by the FER due to similarity with an earlier mark "M/s JAINSONS LITES". The appellant responded on May 1, 2017, claiming the mark "JAINSONS" was adopted in 1978 and had gained goodwill since then. The impugned order dated April 27, 2020, rejected the application under Section 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act 1999, citing likelihood of confusion with earlier trademarks. (Source: Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf, page 2)

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks" (Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/001284, C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021), the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard an appeal by Jainsons Lights Private Limited against the Registrar of Trade Marks. The appellant, represented by Mr. Vikram Grover and Mr. Harish K. Chauhan, argued against the rejection of their trade mark application. The respondent, represented by Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar, countered that the applicant's mark "Jainsons Lights" was phonetically, conceptually, and visually similar to the existing mark "M/s Jainsons Lites" (Mark No. 2242763), which could cause public confusion.

The Senior Examiner had rejected the application, citing the similarity between the two marks, the identical goods and services they covered, and the possibility of public confusion. The court agreed with these findings, noting that the marks were phonetically identical and covered the same goods, including electrical lamps and lights. The court also agreed that the appellant's user claim, dating back to 2014, was subsequent to the claim of user of Rakesh Jain in respect of Mark No. 2242763, which dated back to 2005.

The court ultimately upheld the rejection of the trade mark application, citing Section 11(1)(b) of the Trade Marks Act, which prohibits registration of a trade mark that could cause confusion due to its similarity to an earlier mark. (Source: "Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", pages 1-4 of 8)
tree_structure.pdf_source: 29. Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 3
nodes.summary:
According to page 3 of the PDF "Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the Senior Examiner rejected the appellant's application due to several grounds, including:

* Phonetic similarity between the subject mark and Mark No. 2242763
* Conceptual similarity between the subject mark and Mark No. 2242763
* Identical goods/services
* Possibility of confusion to the public
* Appellant's user claim of 2014 being subsequent to the user claim of 2005
* Lack of significance and uniqueness in the subject mark

The court found no issues with findings (i), (iii), (iv), and (v). Advocate Harish argued that the cited mark is different, but the reply was not satisfactory, and the user claim since 2014 was subsequent to the user of the cited mark. The case is C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021, with Neutral Citation Number 2023/DHC/001284, heard by Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. Hari Shankar. (Source: Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf)
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001284 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021  
Page 3 of 8    
 
ADV. HARISH appeared and argued and submitted that, the cited 
mark is different, heard, and checked the details of application, it 
appeared that. Reply perused not satisfactory, Deceptively and 
phonetically and conceptually similar registered mark no. 
12242763 with the identical goods are on record, so it will cause 
the confusion to the public and in the market, moreover user claim 
since 2014, and user affidavit submitted along with the evidence in 
support has proved the user since 2014 which is subsequent to the 
user of the cited mark, and adv. also fails to establish the 
significance and uniqueness in the adoption of the trade mark, 
since the prefix is a common English term, as there is phonetically 
similarity with the cited mark, hence no difference between cited 
mark and the applicant mark, so; upon considering the material on 
record and submissions made by the adv. And applicant is fail to 
prove the justification for waving off obj. raised under sec. 11 trade 
Mark Act 1999.” 
 
5. 
With some effort, the court has been able to glean, from the 
impugned order, the grounds on which the Senior Examiner has 
rejected the appellant’s application as 
(i) 
phonetic similarity between the subject mark and Mark 
No. 2242763, 
(ii) 
conceptual similarity between the subject mark and Mark 
No. 2242763, 
(iii) 
the fact that both marks were claimed in respect of 
identical goods/services.  
(iv) 
the possibility, therefore, of confusion to the public were 
both marks to be registered, 
(v) 
the user claim of the appellant, of 2014, being subsequent 
to user claim of Mr. Rakesh Jain in respect of Mark No. 
2242763, which was 2005, and 
(vi) 
lack of significance and uniqueness in the subject mark, 
as “lights” was a common English term. 
 
6. 
Of these findings, no cavil, in the opinion of the court, can be 
taken with the findings no. (i), (iii), (iv) and (v). 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.02.2023
15:30:55
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 29. Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 4
nodes.summary: According to page 4 of the PDF "29. Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the court agrees with the Senior Examiner's observations that the subject mark "Jainsons Lights" is phonetically identical to Mark No. 2242763 "M/s Jainsons Lites", and both marks are for identical goods. The appellant's claim of user is also subsequent to the claim of user of Rakesh Jain for Mark No. 2242763. The court cites Section 11(1)(b) of the Trade Marks Act, which prohibits registration of a trade mark if it may cause confusion due to similarity with an earlier mark. The court finds that permitting registration of both marks would likely result in confusion, given their similarity and use for similar goods and services. (Source: PDF "29. Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", Case No. C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021)
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001284 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021  
Page 4 of 8    
 
 
7. 
The court is in agreement with the Senior Examiner in her 
observation that  
(i)  
the subject mark was phonetically identical to Mark No. 
2242763 as the subject mark was “Jainsons Lights” and Mark 
No. 2242763 was “M/s Jainsons Lites”,  
(ii)  
the registration of the marks were sought in respect of 
identical goods, i.e. electrical lamps, lights, electrical goods and 
fittings etc. and   
(iii)  the claim of user, by the appellant, was subsequent to the 
claim of user of Rakesh Jain in respect of Mark no. 2242763. 
 
8. 
The court is also in agreement with the finding of the Senior 
Examiner that permitting registration of both the marks is likely to 
result in confusion. Section 11(1)(b)1 of the Trade Marks Act 
proscribes registration of a trade mark if, owing to its similarity to an 
earlier trade mark, and the identity of similarity of the goods or 
services covered by the two marks, a likelihood of confusion on the 
part of the public can be said to exist.   
 
9. 
There can be no gainsaying the fact that the mark “Jainsons 
Lights” is similar to the mark “Jainsons Lites”. Both marks were used 
in respect of similar goods and services.  
 
                                          
1 11.  
Relative grounds for refusal of registration. –  
(1)  
Save as provided in Section 12, a trade mark shall not be registered if, because of –  
(a)  
its identity with an earlier trade mark and similarity of goods or services 
covered by the trade mark; or 
(b)  
its similarity to an earlier trade mark and the identity or similarity of the goods 
or services covered by the trade mark, 
there exists a likelihood of confusion on the part of the public, which includes the likelihood of association 
with the earlier trade mark. 
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.02.2023
15:30:55
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 29. Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", a legal proceeding (C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021) was held in the High Court of Delhi. The appellant, Jainsons Lights Private Limited, was represented by Mr. Vikram Grover and Mr. Harish K. Chauhan, while the respondent, The Registrar of Trade Marks, was represented by Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar. 

The court examined the likelihood of confusion between the appellant's mark "Jainsons Lights" and the earlier mark "Jainsons Lites" owned by Rakesh Jain. The Senior Examiner had noted that the inclusion of "since 1978" in the appellant's mark did not mitigate the possibility of confusion. The court agreed, stating that an average customer of imperfect recollection would not be able to distinguish between the two marks.

The appellant's argument that the stylized nature of their mark and the inclusion of "since 1978" distinguished it from the earlier mark was rejected. The court held that the dominant part of both marks was "Jainsons", which was identical, increasing the chance of confusion. The court also noted that the words "since 1978" and "M/s" were not sufficient to mitigate the possibility of confusion.

The decision was made on February 23, 2023, and was digitally signed by Sunil Singh Negi. The PDF document provides further details on the legal arguments and proceedings.
tree_structure.pdf_source: 29. Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 5
nodes.summary: According to page 5 of the PDF "29. Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the court is examining the likelihood of confusion between the trade marks "Jainsons Lights" and "Jainsons Lites" under Section 11(1)(b). The appellant's counsel, Mr. Grover, argued that the unique stylised nature of the subject mark and the inclusion of the phrase "since 1978" distinguish it from the earlier mark. However, the court held that from the perspective of a customer of average intelligence and imperfect recollection, the likelihood of confusion cannot be ruled out, especially since both marks are used for identical goods. The court rejected the appeal, citing that the unwary customer may not be able to distinguish between "Lites" and "Lights". (Source: 29. Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf, Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/001284, C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021)
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001284 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021  
Page 5 of 8    
 
10. 
Mr. Grover has sought to contend that the Senior Examiner as 
erred to note (i) the unique stylised nature of the subject mark, which 
distinguished it from the “Jainsons Lites” mark of Rakesh Jain and (ii) 
the inclusion, in the subject mark, of the phrase “since 1978” which 
was essentially intended to indicate tht the mark “Jainsons”, which 
was the prominent part of the subject mark, had been in use since 
1978. 
 
11. 
As already noted, the aspect of likelihood of confusion, for the 
purposes of Section 11(1)(b) has to be examined from the point of 
view of “the public”, as the clause refers to “likelihood of  confusion 
on the part of the public”.  Insofar as the aspect of confusion, in the 
matter of trade marks is concerned, it is settled that the test has to 
apply from the point of view of a customer of average intelligence and 
imperfect recollection. Viewed from the perspective of such a 
customer, the court cannot characterise the finding, of the Senior 
Examiner, that there is a likelihood of confusion between the subject 
mark “Jainsons Lights” and the earlier mark “Jainsons Lites” as 
arbitrary, or otherwise deserving of interference in appeal, especially 
as both the marks were being used in respect of identical goods. The 
unwary customer of average intelligence and imperfect recollection 
cannot be attributed the perspicacity to be able to recollect that, in one 
case, “lights” was spelt “Lites” and, in the other, “Lights”.  Nor can 
the mere inclusion, in the subject mark, of the words “since 1978”, or 
of the word “M/s” in Mark No. 2242763, be regarded as factors which 
would mitigate the possibility of such confusion arising in the minds 
of the customer of average intelligence and imperfect recollection as 
these are elements of a mark which may change from time to time.   
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.02.2023
15:30:55
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 29. Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary: According to page 6 of the PDF "29. Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the court observed that the dominant impression of the mark "JAINSONS LIGHTS" is the name "JAINSONS LIGHTS", not the slogan "since 1978". The average consumer would identify the appellant by its name, rather than the year it started using the mark. The court also noted that the word "lights" or "lites" is an ordinary English word, and the dominant part of both marks is "JAINSONS", which is identical and increases the chance of confusion. The case is C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021, with Jainsons Lights Private Limited as the appellant and the Registrar of Trade Marks as the respondent, heard by Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. Hari Shankar. (Source: PDF page 6)
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001284 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021  
Page 6 of 8    
 
12. 
Besides, in the 
, the dominant impression 
that the average customer, who views the mark without prior 
familiarity with it, would carry with him, is of “JAINSONS 
LIGHTS”, rather than of “since 1978”.  An average consumer, 
realistically speaking, would identify the appellant from its name 
“JAINSONS LIGHTS”, rather than from the year from which it had 
started using the mark “JAINSONS”.  This reality is apparent from the 
mark itself, in which the “since 1978” slogan is in disproportionately 
small letters, as compared to “JAINSONS LIGHTS”.  If the mythical 
customer of imperfect recollection were to to be asked to recollect the 
mark, he would recollect it as “JAINSONS LIGHTS”, not as 
“JAINSONS LIGHTS SINCE 1978”.  Equally, he would recollect 
Mark No. 2242763 as “JAINSONS LITES”, not as “M/s JAINSONS 
LITES”.   
 
13. 
The Senior Examiner is also correct in her observation that 
“lights” – whether spelt “lights” or “lites” – is an ordinary English 
word.  Perhaps it would be more appropriate to hold that the dominant 
part, whether of “JAINSONS LIGHTS” or “JAINSONS LITES”, is 
“JAINSONS”.  That dominant part, in the two marks, is identical, 
thereby exacerbating the chance of confusion.  
 
14. 
 Mr. Grover has also sought to press into service Sections 122 
and 343 of the Trade Marks Act.  
                                          
2 12.  
Registration in the case of honest concurrent use, etc. – In the case of honest concurrent use or 
of other special circumstances which in the opinion of the Registrar, make it proper so to do, he may permit 
the registration by more than one proprietor of the trade marks which are identical or similar (whether any 
such trade mark is already registered or not) in respect of the same or similar goods or services, subject to 
such conditions and limitations, if any, as the Registrar may think fit to impose. 
3 34.  
Saving for vested rights. – Nothing in this Act shall entitle the proprietor or a registered user of 
registered trade mark to interfere with or restrain the use by any person of a trade mark identical with or 
nearly resembling it in relation to goods or services in relation to which that person or a predecessor in title of 
his has continuously used that trade mark from a date prior –  
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.02.2023
15:30:55
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 29. Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi made a decision in the case of Jainsons Lights Private Limited (Appellant) versus The Registrar of Trade Marks (Respondent). The appeal, C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021, was heard by Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. Hari Shankar. 

The Appellant, Jainsons Lights Private Limited, was represented by Mr. Vikram Grover and Mr. Harish K. Chauhan, while the Respondent was represented by Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar, CGSC. The court considered Sections 12 and 34 of the Trade Marks Act, which pertain to the registration of trade marks with "honest concurrent use" or "other special circumstances".

The Appellant claimed prior use of the "Jainsons" mark since 1978, but the court held that this was irrelevant as the Appellant's claim of user for the subject mark was only since 2014. The Respondent, Rakesh Jain, had a prior claim of user since 2005 for Mark No. 2242763. The court dismissed the appeal, stating that the Appellant could not claim prior user over Rakesh Jain and therefore was not entitled to the benefit of Section 34 of the Trade Marks Act. The decision was made on February 22, 2023, and the appeal was dismissed. (Source: Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf)
tree_structure.pdf_source: 29. Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 7
nodes.summary: According to page 7 of the PDF "29. Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the court rejected the appellant's submission that Section 12 of the Trade Marks Act would vitiate the impugned order. The appellant, Jainsons Lights Private Limited, argued that the case involved "other special circumstances" due to their prior use of the "Jainsons" mark since 1978. However, the court noted that Section 34 of the Trade Marks Act requires prior use and registration, which the appellant failed to establish, as their claim of use was from 2014, while the respondent's claim was from 2005. The court, led by Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. Hari Shankar, made this decision in the case C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021, with the Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/001284.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001284 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021  
Page 7 of 8    
 
15. 
I am, unfortunately, unable to accept his submission that either 
of these provisions would serve to vitiate the impugned order.  Section 
12 permits the Registrar, in an appropriate case, to allow registration 
of a mark which is identical, or similar to an earlier trade mark, where 
the case is one of “honest concurrent use”, or where there are “other 
special circumstances”.  
 
16. 
Mr. Grover seeks to submit that the present case has to be 
regarded as one involving “other special circumstances”, the “special 
circumstance” being that the “Jainsons” mark had been in use by his 
client since 1978.  For this purpose, Mr. Grover seeks to submit that 
Section 12 may be read in conjunction with Section 34 of the Trade 
Marks Act.    
 
17. 
Section 34 of the Trade Marks Act allows the Registrar to 
register a trade mark which is identical with or nearly resembling an 
earlier trade mark, in respect of identical goods or services, provided 
the user of the former is prior in point of time both to registration and 
user of the latter.  
 
18. 
This defence obviously, cannot come to the aid of the appellant, 
as the claim of user of the appellant, in respect of the subject trade 
mark, is of 2014, whereas the user claim of Rakesh Jain in respect of 
Mark No. 2242763 is of 2005.  Though Mr Grover emphasizes that 
the mark “JAINSONS” was being used since 1978, that is irrelevant.  
The court, while applying Section 34, has to take into account the 
                                                                                                                   
(a)  
to the use of the first-mentioned trade mark in relation to those goods or services be the 
proprietor or a predecessor in title of his; or 
(b)  
to the date of registration of the first-mentioned trade mark in respect of those goods or 
services in the name of the proprietor of a predecessor in title of his; 
whichever is the earlier, and the Registrar shall not refuse (on such use being proved) to register the second 
mentioned trade mark by reason only of the registration of the first-mentioned trade mark. 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.02.2023
15:30:55
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 29. Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 8
nodes.summary: According to page 8 of the PDF "29. Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the court ruled in favor of the respondent. The appellant, Jainsons Lights Private Limited, claimed user of the subject mark since 1978, but this is only a part of the complete mark. The appellant itself claimed user of the complete mark since 2014, which means it cannot claim prior user over Rakesh Jain to entitle it to the benefit of Section 34 of the Trade Marks Act. The appeal (C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021) was dismissed by Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. Hari Shankar on February 22, 2023. The court found no case for interference with the impugned order dated April 27, 2020. (Source: 29. Jainsons Lights Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf)
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001284 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 113/2021  
Page 8 of 8    
 
claim of user in respect of the subject mark which, in the present case, 
is “
”.  “Since 1978” is only a part of the 
complete 
 mark, and user, in respect of the 
complete mark, is claimed, by the appellant itself, since 2014. 
 
19. 
Inasmuch as the appellant itself has claimed user, while 
applying for subject mark, of 2014, it cannot claim prior user over 
Rakesh Jain, so as to entitle it to the benefit of Section 34 of the Trade 
Marks Act.  
 
20. 
For the aforesaid reasons, I do not find that a case for 
interference with impugned order dated 27th April 2020 can be said to 
exist.  
 
21. 
The appeal is accordingly dismissed.  
 
 
 
C. HARI SHANKAR, J. 
 
FEBRUARY 22, 2023 
 
dsn 
 
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.02.2023
15:30:55
Signature Not Verified
